An algebra $B$ over a ring $A$ is defined as a ring homomorphism $A \longrightarrow B$. A homomorphism between two $A$-algebras $B$ and $C$ is a ring homomorphism $B \longrightarrow C$ that is compatible with the defining homomorphisms $A \longrightarrow B$ and $A \longrightarrow C$, ensuring the commutativity of the diagram involving these maps.
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.

This concept is inherently related to the structure of modules and the ring over which they are defined, but it does not require the structure of an algebra over a ring.

On the other hand, an Algebra over a Ring involves a more complex structure involving a ring homomorphism from a ring A to another structure B, which itself must also be a ring. This concept is used to study ring extensions and the interaction between different ring structures, but it is not necessary for defining or understanding torsion in modules.
